metadata.case_name: Archakas and Karnam of Sri Venkateswaraswami Temple v. Board of Commissioners for Hindu Religious Endowments

facts.text: Temple dedicated to Sri Venkateswaraswami in Dwaraka Tirumalai village, West Godavari district, Andhra Pradesh, administered under scheme settled on 28th August 1930 by Subordinate Judge of Eluru in Original Suit No. 1 of 1925 under S.92 CPC by worshippers.

Hereditary trustees: family of Zamindars of Mylavaram. Controversies over rights of archakas and Karnam, including remuneration, decided in OS 1/1925; appeals to High Court dismissed, scheme confirmed.
Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act (Act 11 of 1927) enacted during pendency of OS 1/1925; temple is 'excepted temple' due to hereditary trusteeship.
Scheme under S.92 CPC deemed scheme under Act per S.75; modifiable under S.57(9) by court on application by Board, trustee or person interested.

Board filed O.P. 76/1947 on 3 August 1947 in District Court, West Godavari, for modification of scheme; several modifications accepted, but remuneration of archakas and Karnam not varied by District Judge.

Archakas entitled to half share in dibbi collections (votive offerings, ~Rs.50,000/year), share in bhogam, fees for marriages/Upanayanams, Dweeparadhana, Padaraksha Kanukalu, pumpkins; recognised by custom, usage, prior court decrees.
Karnam entitled to 1/16th share (one anna) of temple's half share in dibbi collections by custom; duties include sitting at dibbi, maintaining chitta of offerings.

District Judge in O.P.76/1947 refused to disturb remuneration of archakas and Karnam, citing established usage, custom, decrees; para 14 allowed half dibbi share and other emoluments per decrees/usage; para 17 allowed Karnam customary share if personally performing duties or with approved deputy paid by him.

Board appealed to High Court (Appeal Suit No. 357/1951); High Court allowed appeal in part, modified para 14 to restrict archakas to half dibbi + share in pumpkins/rice at calf dedication, no other perquisites; dismissed archakas' cross-objections.
High Court modified para 17 for Karnam: salary Rs.25/mensem, deputy acceptable to executive officer; reasons: duties lessened by executive officer, practice of deputies.
Certificates under Art.133 granted; CA 531/1961 by Karnam, CA 532/1961 by Archakas.
Seven families of hereditary archakas divide shares; worship 5AM-9PM daily, 40-50 festivals/year; expenses for cooks etc.
Board's OP para 7g conceded half dibbi share to archakas (>Rs.18,000/year), sought bar on other remuneration/lands; para 7h objected to bhogam share.
Board's appeal ground 13 only questioned half dibbi share quantum, no objection to bhogam/other items.
Board's OP para 8g for Karnam: complains deputy underpaid, work inadequate; sought payment only actual deputy salary from dibbi if deputy employed.
Scheme para 23 and S.79 Act protect established usage, rights, emoluments, perquisites by custom.

legal_issues.text: Whether appeal lay from District Judge's order under S.57(9) of the Act to High Court.
Whether High Court erred in modifying para 14 of scheme restricting archakas' remuneration to half dibbi share + pumpkins/rice, excluding other perquisites upheld by District Judge.
Whether High Court erred in modifying para 17 reducing Karnam's remuneration to Rs.25/mensem regardless of personal duty.

petitioner_arguments.text: No appeal lay from District Judge's order in O.P. under S.57(9) as not a decree under S.2(2) CPC, no specific appeal provision in Act like S.84; relied on Rajagopala Chettiar Full Bench.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.57(9) Act, S.2(2), S.96 CPC; Rajagopala Chettiar v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred on merits: Board's OP conceded half dibbi, only disputed other items like bhogam; appeal grounds didn't challenge bhogam/others; items established by custom, decrees, no vagueness as scheme worked 25+ years without issue; no justification to interfere.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: S.79 Act; prior decrees in OS 1/1925

petitioner_arguments.text: For Karnam: Board's prayer only for reduced pay if deputy employed, not abolition or fixed salary; custom requires personal duty for full share or approved deputy; executive officer doesn't eliminate Karnam duties.

respondent_arguments.text: Para 14 too vague, likely to cause difficulties; restrict archakas to half dibbi + pumpkins/rice at calf dedication; other claims excessive, like archakas elsewhere claiming lands.
Karnam's duties lessened by executive officer accounts; practice of deputies; fix salary Rs.25/mensem, deputy approved by executive officer; benefits temple.

court_reasoning.text: Appeal competent: S.57(9) modifies scheme-decree under S.92 CPC (deemed under S.75); modification/cancellation affects decree, resultant order is decree under S.2(2) CPC, appealable under S.96 CPC; unlike S.84(2) applications; liberty to modify akin to reserved liberty in decree.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Order under S.57(9) is decree as it modifies/vacates prior scheme-decree.

court_reasoning.text: On merits for archakas: No justification on pleadings/evidence; Board conceded dibbi half, disputed only bhogam/lands; appeal didn't challenge bhogam; items fixed by prior decrees/custom, not vague; scheme worked 25 years without issue; High Court reasoning not open.
Remuneration by custom for services; change possible if circumstances alter, but no basis here.

For Karnam: Board's prayer only lesser pay if deputy, not fixed salary/abolition; custom: personal duty or approved deputy for full share; para 17 balanced rights; executive officer doesn't eliminate office; no justification to reduce to nominal Rs.25.

holdings.text: Appeal from District Judge's order under S.57(9) lies to High Court as it modifies scheme-decree.
Restore para 14 as per District Judge: archakas entitled to half dibbi + other emoluments/perquisites per decrees/usage/custom.
Restore para 17 as per District Judge: Karnam entitled to customary 1/16th share if personally performs duties; deputy only with approval, paid by Karnam.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajagopala Chettiar v. Hindu Religious Endowments Board
precedents_cited.relevance: Held no appeal from S.84(2) order as not decree; distinguished as S.57(9) modifies decree unlike S.84(2) application.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act, 1927
statutes_cited.relevance: S.57(9) for modification of deemed scheme by court application; S.75 deems prior S.92 scheme as Act scheme; S.79 protects custom/usage/emoluments; S.84 for other appeals.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: S.92 for original scheme suit; S.2(2) defines decree; S.96 for appeals from decrees.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Both Civil Appeals Nos. 531 and 532 of 1961 allowed; para 14 and 17 of scheme as modified by District Judge in O.P.76/1947 restored; appellants entitled to costs in Supreme Court from respondents 1 and 2.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of District Judge's scheme provisions on remuneration for archakas and Karnam.
outcome.costs: Appellants entitled to costs in this Court from respondents 1 and 2.

key_quotes.text: "The archakas and the Karnam of the temple were allowed to take their respective shares in the collections in dibbi for a long time and though the origin of such a right is not known, it cannot be said that it had no legal origin."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Recognises long usage/custom for dibbi shares from 1925 judgment.

key_quotes.text: "Save as otherwise expressly provided in or under this Act nothing herein contained shall affect any established usage of a math or temple or the rights, honours, emoluments and perquisites to which any person may by custom or otherwise be entitled."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "So far as the archakas, and the karnam are concerned most of their rights are governed by the decrees, usage, custom, etc., and they should be adhered to."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court

key_quotes.text: Order under S.57(9) modifies scheme-decree, hence a decree appealable under S.96 CPC.
key_quotes.speaker: court
